facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 396-413 of 1963 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 26, 1961 of the Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 396-413 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 26, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in Writ Appeals Nos. 104-106, 107, 109, 112, 108, 113, 114, 111, 115, 116, 119, 120, 123, 124 and 122 of 1964.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on April 10, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: P. Gopalan Nambiar, Advocate-General, Kerala and V. A. Seyid Muhammed, for the respondent  in all the appeals . April 10, 1964. The judgment Of GAJENDRAGADKAR, C.J., SHAH AND SIKRI JJ. was delivered by SHAH J.

facts.text: Sales-tax Officer, Special Circle Ernakulam assessed the appellants under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act XI of 1125 M.E. for sales of tea chests at auctions in Fort Cochin in 1956-57 to 1958-59.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-The Sales-tax Officer, Special Circle Ernakulam assessed the appellants under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act XI of 1125 M.E., to pay sales-tax on transactions of sale of tea chests at the auctions held at Fort Cochin in the years 1956-57 to 1958-59, rejecting their contention that the sales were exempted from tax by virtue of Art. 286(1)(b) of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants petitioned the High Court of Kerala for writs of certiorari quashing assessment orders and prohibition restraining collection of tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then petitioned the High Court of Kerala for writs of certiorari quashing the orders of assessment and for writs of prohibition restraining the Sales-tax Officer from proceeding with the collection of tax in pursuance of the orders of assessment.

facts.text: Vaidialingam J. rejected the petitions and the order was confirmed by Division Bench of Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Vaidialingam J., rejected the petitions and his order was confirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court of Kerala. With special leave, the appellants have appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Transactions of sale are in tea, a controlled commodity.

anchor.surface_text: The transactions of sale sought to be taxed by the Revenue authorities are in tea, which is a controlled commodity.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Tea Act 19 of 1953 for control of tea industry.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament enacted the Tea Act  19 of 1953  to provide for the control by the Union of the tea industry, including the control of cultivation of tea in, and of export of tea from, India and for that purpose to establish a Tea Board and to levy customs duty on tea exported from India.

facts.text: Manufacturer of tea obtains export quota rights from Tea Board on payment of licence fee.

anchor.surface_text: Trade in tea in the State of Kerala-internal as well as export-is carried on through certain defined channels. A manufacturer of tea applies for and obtains from the Tea Board allotment of export quota rights on payment of the necessary licence fee.

facts.text: Manufactured tea chests sent to M/s. T. Stanes & Co. Ltd. who warehouse at Willingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: The manufactured tea in chests is then sent to M s. T. Stanes Company Ltd. who warehouse the chests at Willingdon Island.

facts.text: Tea chests sold by public auction through brokers at Fort Cochin with export quota rights.

anchor.surface_text: Chests of tea are then sold by public auction through brokers at Fort Cochin. With the chests of tea for which export quota rights are obtained, export quota rights are sold by the auctioneer.

facts.text: Bids at auction given by agents or intermediaries in Cochin of foreign buyers.

anchor.surface_text: At the auction sale, bids for tea chests with export quota rights are given by the agents or intermediaries in Cochin of foreign buyers.

facts.text: Tea chests delivered by M/s. T. Stanes & Co. Ltd. to purchasers whose bids accepted.

anchor.surface_text: Tea chests are delivered at the warehouses by M s. T. Stanes Company Ltd. to the purchasers whose bids are accepted.

facts.text: Agents of foreign buyers obtain licences from Central Government under export quota rights and export tea.

anchor.surface_text: The agents or intermediaries of the foreign buyers then obtain licences from the Central Government for export of tea chests under the export quota rights vested in them under the purchases made at the auction sales.

facts.text: Sellers know that bids offered by buyers for purpose of export and bidders are agents of foreign buyers.

anchor.surface_text: When auctions of tea with the export rights are held at Fort Cochin, it is in this group of appeals common ground, sellers on whose behalf the auctioneer acts as the agent know that bids are offered by the buyers of tea for the purpose of export.

facts.text: No finding by Sales-tax authorities that purchasers at auction were agents of foreign buyers, but case argued on that footing.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there is no finding by the Sales-tax authorities that the respective purchasers at the auction were agents of foreign buyers, but the Advocate appearing on behalf of the State argued the case before the High Court on the footing that the bids were offered at the auctions by the agents or intermediaries or foreign buyers,

facts.text: Vaidialingam J. held sales complete when bids accepted and sellers had no concern with export.

anchor.surface_text: Vaidialingam J., held that transactions of sale were complete when bids for purchase of tea together with the export quota rights were accepted, and the sellers had no concern with the actual export which was effected by the auction purchasers to their foreign principals.

facts.text: High Court held no intimate connection between sale and export as no obligation to export.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal held that the ban imposed by Art. 286(1)(b) predicated a casual connection between the sale and the export-a connection which is intimate and real. The sale, it was said, must inextricably be bound up with the export and form an integral part thereof,

facts.text: Appellants are 18 tea estates growing and manufacturing tea.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are 18 tea estates which are carrying on the business of growing and manufacturing tea in their estates.

facts.text: Tea sold was actually exported out of India.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the tea sold under the transactions involved in these appeals was actually exported out of the territory of India.

facts.text: Persons who bid at auction at Fort Cochin were agents of foreign buyers and purchased under directions of foreign principals.

anchor.surface_text: Pausing here we should mention that there is no dispute  1  that the persons who bid at the auction at Fort Cochin and purchased the teas of the assessees were agents of foreign buyers or  2  regarding their having made these purchases under the directions of their foreign principals

facts.text: Assessees obtained export quotas to effect exports of tea grown and processed by them.

anchor.surface_text: To proceed with the facts, the assessees had applied for and obtained export quotas with a view to effect exports of a quantity of tea grown and processed by them.

facts.text: Sales at Fort Cochin effected along with export rights, purchaser obtains transfer of export quota right.

anchor.surface_text: The sales at Fort Cochin were effected along with the export rights ,- granted to the Appellant estates. the contract being that the purchaser at the auction would obtain a transfer of the export quota right of that estate whose tea he purchased to the extent needed to effect export of the tea purchased.

facts.text: Purchasers obtained export licences based on transfers and effected exports.

anchor.surface_text: The purchases were thus made only on the basis that the export rights of the seller would be transferred to the buyer and on the basis of these transfers the purchasers obtained export licences from Government for exporting the tea and effected the exports.

facts.text: Agents fulfilled obligation to ship goods to foreign destinations.

anchor.surface_text: There was proof by the certificates produced that these agents had fulfilled their obligations to their principals and had shipped the goods bought as early as practicable to foreign destinations.

facts.text: Assessing authorities accepted statements of assessees without requiring evidence.

anchor.surface_text: When the assessees sought an opportunity to adduce evidence as to the facts which they offered to prove to establish their claim to the constitutional protection, the assessing authorities accepted their statements as correct and did not desire them to adduce evidence and so no detailed evidence was led.

issues.text: Is the sale by auction to the agent or intermediary of the foreign buyer, in the course of export within the meaning of Art. 286(1) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Is the sale by auction to the agent of intermediary of the foreign buyer, in the companrse of export within the meaning of Art. 286 1  of the Constitution? If the sale is in the companrse of export out of the territory of India.

issues.text: The question for consideration is whether these sales effected by the appellants are, as they claim, sales in the course of export.

anchor.surface_text: The question for companysideration is whether these sales effected by the appellants are, as they claim, sales in the companyrse of export.

issues.text: Correctness of this view [High Court holding that there was no intimate connection between sale and export] is challenged in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal held that the ban imposd by Art. 286 1  b  predicated a casual compannection between the sale and the export-a compan- nection which is intimate and real. [...] Correctness of this view is challenged in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: To companystitute a sale in the companyrse of export of goods out of the territory of India, companymon intention of the parties to the transaction to export the goods followed by actual export of the goods, to a foreign destination is necessary.

issues.text: Whether the sales occasion the export such that there is an integrated connection between sale and export?

holdings.text: A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of the export of the goods out of the territory of India only if the sale or purchase either occasions such export or is effected by a transfer of documents of title to the goods after the goods have crossed the customs frontiers of India.

anchor.surface_text: under the Central Sales Tax Act 74 of 1956 enacted by s. 5 that a sale or purchase of goods. shall be deemed to take place in the course of the export of the goods out of the territory of India only if the sale or purchase

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament defined via CST Act s.5 post Sixth Amendment, legislative recognition of prior judicial view in Bombay Co. and Shanmugha Vilas.

holdings.text: To constitute a sale in the course of export, there must be common intention to export, obligation to export imposed by statute, contract, mutual understanding or nature of transaction, and actual export, with integrated activities forming single transaction.

anchor.surface_text: To constitute a sale in the course of export of goods out of the territory of India, common intention of the parties to the transaction to export the goods followed by actual export of the goods, to a foreign destination is necessary. But intention to export and actual exportation are not sufficient

holdings.reasoning_summary: Etymological and precedential analysis (Bombay Co., Shanmugha Vilas); distinguishes mere sales for export from those occasioning export via unbreakable bond.

holdings.text: Knowledge that goods are intended for export and sale of export quota rights with goods does not create integral connection making sale part of course of export.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No bond linking sale and export; seller has no control post-sale; quota merely enables licence, no compulsion.

holdings.text: There is no statutory obligation under Tea Act upon purchaser to export tea chests bought with export quota rights; quota enables but does not compel export.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of Tea Act ss.17,21; transferable quota, no embargo on non-export; diversion to internal consumption possible.

holdings.text: The transactions of sale of tea chests with export quota rights at Fort Cochin auctions do not occasion export and are not sales in the course of export under Art.286(1)(b).
holdings.reasoning_summary: No integral bond or obligation; sales complete on bid acceptance; sellers unconcerned with export; applies integrated activities test to facts.

holdings.text: Sales preceding the export sale, even if procured for export, are not exempt under Art.286(1)(b) unless directly and integrally connected to the export.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of precedents (Shanmugha Vilas, Gurviah Naidu, Mysore Spinning, East India Tobacco, Daulatram); first of two sales not in course unless property passes in export stream.

holdings.text: The Tea Act does not impose any obligation on the quota holder or transferee to export the goods covered by the quota.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provisions optional; economic factors may compel but no legal compulsion; rejects claim of implicit obligation from transfer.

holdings.text: Appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Art.286(1)(b) test to facts; sales for export but taxable by state.
